Prepares for Abdominal Exam

subSteps.content: Instructs the patient to lay supine & inquires about painful areas
Positions patient arms at side or across chest, table extended, with knees flexed
Positions drape, exposing area from xiphoid to symphysis pubis

steps.title: Inspects Abdomen using tangential lighting
Auscultates all 4 quadrants for Bowel Sounds
steps.instructions: with diaphragm clockwise, starting at RLQ

steps.title: Auscultates for Vascular Sounds with bell

subSteps.content: Epigastric & Umbilical area - Comments on: Venous hum, presence or absence
Aorta
Bilateral Renal Arteries
Bilateral Iliac Arteries
Bilateral Femoral Arteries

steps.title: Palpates bilateral Femoral Pulses
Palpates bilateral horizontal & vertical Inguinal Lymph Nodes
Percusses all 4 quadrants of Abdomen
Percusses Liver Borders

subSteps.content: Upper border: percuss intercostal spaces along the right midclavicular line starting from an area of lung resonance down, marking the first area of dullness
Lower border: percuss along the right midclavicular line starting from an area of intestinal tympany up (just below umbilicus), marking the first area of dullness
Measure liver span in cm

steps.title: Percusses Spleen

subSteps.content: Use Castell's Method
Follow anterior axillary line to last intercostal space (approximately 9th or 10th intercostal space)
Instruct patient to exhale completely and percuss for tympany
Instruct patient to inhale and percuss for change to dullness

steps.title: Performs Light Palpation of abdomen
Performs Deep Palpation of abdomen
Palpates Liver

subSteps.content: Places left hand under thorax parallel to 11-12th ribs
Places right fingertips lightly below costal margin at MCL
Instructs patient to take a deep breath & blow it out completely
On exhale, palpates with right fingertips & applies upward pressure with left
Holds position as patient inhales

steps.title: Palpates Epigastric, Umbilical & Incision Areas for hernias

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to cough or strain while palpating with palmer surface of hand

steps.title: Tests for Cholecystitis with Murphey's sign

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to exhale completely
Deeply palpates below right costal margin at mid-clavicular line with upward pressure & instructs patient to inhale

steps.title: Tests for Peritonitis with Rebound Tenderness

subSteps.content: Palpates McBurney's point slowly & deeply, releasing pressure suddenly

steps.title: Tests for RLQ Peritonitis with Rovsing Sign

subSteps.content: Palpates LLQ slowly & deeply, releasing pressure suddenly

steps.title: Tests for Retrocecal Appendicitis with Psoas sign

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to actively flex leg at hip against resistance with knee flexed
Instruct patient to lie on left side and hyperflex right hip

steps.title: Tests for Pelvic Appendicitis with Obturator sign

subSteps.content: Position patient with hip & knee flexed at 90 degrees, supporting ankle & knee
Passively internally rotate leg at hip

steps.title: Percusses bilateral Kidneys for CVA Tenderness

subSteps.content: Places palmar surface of hand at costovertebral angle
Make fist with other hand, strikes first hand
Observes patient for signs of tenderness or pain

steps.title: Performs Hand Hygiene

Inspects Behavior
Inspects Precordium
Palpates Precordium

subSteps.content: Identifies location of PMI

steps.title: Auscultates 5 areas of Heart
steps.instructions: with diaphragm & bell, several cardiac cycles per area

subSteps.content: Aortic, 2nd ICS, RSB (S2 > S1)
Pulmonic, 2nd ICS, LSB (S2 > S1)
Erbs Point – 3rd ICS LSB (S2 = S1)
Instructs patient to lift breast if necessary
Tricuspid – 4th ICS LSB (S1 > S2)
Mitral (Apical) - 5th ICS MCL (S1 > S2)

comments: Murmur, presence or absence, location, characteristics

steps.title: Auscultates Apical Heart Rate
steps.instructions: at Mitral area for one full minute

steps.title: Auscultates for Aortic Regurgitation & Mitral Stenosis

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to lean forward, exhale, & hold breath
Listens with diaphragm at LSB at apex/base
Instruct patient to lie in the left lateral decubitus position
Listens with bell at apical impulse
Palpates carotid impulse to identify systole and diastole

steps.title: Inspects Thorax
comments: Symmetric or paradoxical chest rise, retractions

steps.title: Palpates Thorax
Auscultates Anterior Thorax with diaphragm

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to breathe deep with mouth open
Systematic progression side to side, from apex to base, at intercostal spaces
Instructs patient to lift breast if necessary

comments: Clarity of lung sounds, adventitious sounds (location, quality, grade)

steps.title: Auscultates Posterior Thorax with diaphragm

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to breathe through mouth, cross arms at waist, head forward
Systematic progression side to side, from apex to base, at intercostal spaces
Includes lateral fields
At least 1 full cycle at each point

comments: Clarity of lung sounds, adventitious sounds (location, quality, grade)

steps.title: Auscultates for Bronchophony

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to repeat "99" while auscultating posterior lung fields

steps.title: Auscultates for Egophony

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to repeat "eeee" while auscultating posterior lung fields

steps.title: Auscultates for Whisper Pectoriloquy

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to whisper "123" while auscultating posterior lung fields

steps.title: Appropriately concludes the exam with the patient
Ensures Privacy

subSteps.content: Introduces self & explains role
Confirms Patient Identity
Informs patient they will be verbally describing the examination

steps.title: Performs Hand Hygiene
Inspects Appearance
Inspects Behavior
Inspects Skull, Scalp & Hair
Palpates Skull
Tests CN VII – Facial

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to: Frown
Elevate forehead or raise eyebrows
Clench & show teeth
Smile
Puff & blow out cheeks
Close eyes firmly – tries to open against resistance, no pressure on the globe
Inspects Facial Features, observes & comments on symmetry

steps.title: Palpates bilateral Temporal Arteries simultaneously
Tests CN V – Trigeminal

subSteps.content: Motor: Places hands on patient's cheeks & temples
Instructs patient to contract & relax masseter muscles by clenching teeth
Tests strength by pushing down on mandible against resistance
Sensory: Instructs patient to close eyes & say "now" when feeling cotton touch their face
Uses light touch with wisp of cotton over 3 nerve divisions bilaterally

comments: Bilateral motor function, intact or deficit
Bilateral sensory function, intact or deficit

steps.title: Inspects bilateral Eyebrows, Orbital Areas & Eyelids
comments: Orbital edema, sagging tissue, lesions, or nodules

steps.title: Inspects the Bulbar & Palpebral Conjunctivae & Sclerae
Palpates bilateral Lacrimal Glands & Sac
Tests CN II, III (Optic, Oculomotor)

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to focus at a far fixed point and then on a near fixed point, observes pupillary response
Inspects bilateral eyes with pen light, observes pupillary response
Perform swinging light test, observes pupillary response

comments: Pupillary reflex, direct, consensual, and afferent accommodation

steps.title: Tests CN III, IV, VI (Oculomotor, Trochlear, Abducens)

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to follow the pen with eyes without moving head
Performs six cardinal fields of gaze

comments: Nystagmus, presence or absence, and plane of movement

steps.title: Tests Visual Acuity (CN II, Optic)

subSteps.content: Follows instructions on card
Instructs patient to read the smallest line they can with both eyes, & each eye separately (if corrected vision, assess with glasses/contacts)

steps.title: Tests Visual Fields (CN II, Optic)

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to stare straight ahead at your nose
Have patient cover one eye at a time while assessing visual field of uncovered eye
Patient to state when practitioner's fingers in field of view

steps.title: Performs Ophthalmoscopic exam

subSteps.content: Prepares: Explains exam, gives patient instructions & permission to ask for rest
Positions patient at eye level
Adjusts light shape & intensity & focuses ophthalmoscope
Cracks open the door & darkens room to dilate pupils
Performs: Right hand with right eye; left hand with left eye
Braces other hand on forehead, thumb above eyebrow
No pressure on globe & no pulling on eyelids
Inspects all 4 quadrants of each eye

comments: Macula characteristics (instructs patient to look directly at light)

steps.title: Inspects & palpates bilaterally the Pinna, Tragus & Mastoid Area
Inspects bilateral Auditory Canals & Tympanic Membranes

subSteps.content: Braces Otoscope
Selects appropriate cover
Pulls gently back & up on antihelix of pinna to adjust for better exposure

comments: TM color, transparency, contour, light reflex, & perforations

steps.title: Tests CN VIII (Acoustic)

subSteps.content: Performs Whisper Test on each ear
Instructs patient to repeat whisper & occlude opposite ear
Stands behind patient, whispers two-syllable word from distance of 2 feet

steps.title: Tests for Conductive & Sensorineural Hearing Loss

subSteps.content: Weber Test: places tuning fork base at center of forehead, asks patient which ear hears the sound loudest

Rhinne Test: places tuning fork base at mastoid bone, asks patient to indicate when sound is no longer heard, holds fork tines 1 inch from the ear, asks patient to indicate when sound is no longer heard

steps.title: Palpates Frontal & Maxillary Sinuses
Inspects & palpates External Nose
Tests bilateral Nare Patency
Inspects Nasal Mucosa & Nasal Septum
Inspects Lips, Gingivae, & Teeth
Inspects the Tongue & Buccal Mucosa
comments: Presence of piercings, ulcerations or lesions

steps.title: Tests CN XII (Hypoglossal)
comments: Ability to move toward the nose & chin

steps.title: Tests CN X (Vagus)
steps.instructions: by inspecting Oropharynx as patient says "Ah"

steps.title: Tests CN IX & X (Glossopharyngeal & Vagus)
Inspects Neck
Palpates bilateral Carotid Arteries separately
Auscultates bilateral Carotid Arteries for bruits

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to hold breath & turn head away while auscultating

steps.title: Palpates Thyroid Gland

subSteps.content: Locates isthmus below cricoid cartilage, asks patient to swallow to confirm
Asks patient to flex neck slightly forward & to the side being examined
Palpates lateral lobes deep to anterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle
Confirms findings by having patient swallow

steps.title: Palpates bilateral Lymph Nodes simultaneously

subSteps.content: Preauricular
Postauricular
Occipital
Parotid
Tonsillar
Submandibular
Submental
Anterior Cervical
Posterior Cervical
Supraclavicular
Infraclavicular

steps.title: Tests CN XI (Spinal Accessory)

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to push against your hand by turning head
Places hand on the side of the patients jaw & provides resistance
Instructs patient to shrug their shoulders & hold that position as you apply downward pressure

Ensures Privacy

subSteps.content: Introduces self & explains role
Confirms Patient Identity

steps.title: Performs Hand Hygiene
Inspects Appearance
Inspects Behavior
Assesses Mood
Assess Orientation to person, time, and place

subSteps.content: What is your name and DOB?
What is today's date and season of the year?
What is the name of this place or building?

steps.title: Tests Memory

subSteps.content: Recent (short-term): ex. "What did you eat for breakfast?"
Remote (long-term): ex. "What did you do for your last birthday?"
Short-term Recall & Attention: Instruct patient to repeat 3 unrelated objects immediately & after 5 minutes

steps.title: Tests Coordination

subSteps.content: Arm Dystaxia: Instructs patient to alternate hands touching nose, eyes closed
Rapid Alternating Movements: Instructs patient to touch each finger to the thumb of the same hand, both hands simultaneously, as fast as possible
Leg Dystaxia: Instruct patient to run heel from opposite knee down shin in a straight line

steps.title: Tests Sensory Function
steps.instructions: instructs patient to close eyes throughout

subSteps.content: Exteroceptive Sensation: Instructs patient to say "dull" or "sharp" when felt
Touches extremities, first distal, then proximal, with cotton & toothpick
Proprioception: Instructs patient to say "up" or "down"
Holding a distal joint at the sides, position up or down, repeat bilaterally
Graphesthesia: Instructs patient to identify the number or letter
Draws letter or number on palm, repeat bilaterally
Stereognosis: Instructs patient to identify object & places object in patient's hand

steps.title: Tests Deep Tendon Reflexes bilaterally
steps.instructions: instructs patient to relax, supports position

subSteps.content: Biceps: elbow partially flexed and forearm pronated with palm down, places thumb on biceps tendon, strikes tendon indirectly by striking hammer on finger

Triceps: sitting or supported technique. Sitting, flex arm at elbow with palm toward body and pull slightly across chest, strikes tendon above olecranon process just above elbow; Supported, support elbow at 90 degrees abduction and instruct patient to allow arm to go limp, strikes tendon above olecranon process
Brachioradialis: rest hand on lap with forearm partly pronated, strikes tendon above radial styloid process
Patellar: sitting position with feet dangling, strikes patellar tendon just below patella
Achilles: partially dorsiflex foot at ankle, strikes achilles tendon

steps.title: Inspects, palpates, and tests active ROM of Neck

subSteps.content: Flexion (45°)
Extension (55°)
Rotation (70°)
Lateral Bending (40°)

steps.title: Inspects, palpates, and tests active ROM of bilateral Shoulders

subSteps.content: Identifies AC Joint
Flexion (180°)
Extension (60°)
Abduction (180°)
Adduction (50° - 90°)
Internal & External Rotation (90°)

steps.title: Tests for Impingement

subSteps.content: Painful Arc Test: fully abducts shoulder to 180°
Neer's Sign: Internally rotate arm & passively flex shoulder
Hawkins-Kennedy Test: abducts shoulder 90° with palm facing down, internally rotates forearm

steps.title: Tests Shoulder Stability

subSteps.content: Patient positioned supine on exam table
Shoulder passively abducted 90° and elbow flexed 90°, externally rotate forearm; apply anterior pressure on humerus to stabilize

steps.title: Tests for AC Joint disorder

subSteps.content: Rest hand on top of opposite shoulder, press elbow to push hand back

steps.title: Tests for Scapular Instability

subSteps.content: Places dorsum of hand against mid-lumbar spine
Instructs patient to lift their hand away from their back; repeat while applying resistance

steps.title: Inspects, palpates, and tests active ROM of bilateral Elbows

subSteps.content: Identifies medial & lateral Epicondyles & Olecranon Process
Flexion (160°)
Extension (180°)
Supination & Pronation (90°)

steps.title: Tests for Epicondylitis

subSteps.content: Medial (Golfer's Elbow): palpate medial epicondyle, passively supinate forearm with elbow 90° flexed & supported, extends wrist/fingers and extends elbow fully
Lateral (Tennis Elbow): palpate lateral epicondyle, passively pronate forearm with elbow 90° flexion & supported, flexes wrist/fist and extends elbow fully

steps.title: Inspects, palpates, and tests active ROM of bilateral Wrists

subSteps.content: Extension (70°)
Flexion (70 - 90°)
Radial deviation (20°)
Ulnar deviation (30-55°)

steps.title: Inspects, palpates, and tests active ROM of bilateral Hands & Fingers

subSteps.content: Identifies "Snuffbox"
Instructs patient to make fist with thumb across knuckles
Extend and spread/flare fingers
Touch each digit to thumb

comments: Number, completeness, position, shape, & symmetry of digits

steps.title: Tests bilateral Grip Strength
Tests for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

subSteps.content: Tinel's Sign: Percusses over median nerve in carpal tunnel
Phalen's Sign: Holds wrists in complete flexion, dorsums together for 60 seconds
Carpal Compression Test: With wrist supinated, applies pressure with both thumbs over median nerve in carpal tunnel

steps.title: Tests for de Quervain Tenosynovitis

subSteps.content: Finkelstein Test: Grasps thumb, ulnar deviates the hand

steps.title: Tests for Meningeal Signs

subSteps.content: Brudzinski's Sign: Place one hand on chest, attempt to flex neck with other
Kernig's Sign: Flex hip and knee to 90 degrees and then slowly extend leg and straighten knee

steps.title: Tests Babinski Reflex

subSteps.content: Drag handle of reflex hammer firmly across lateral aspect of the sole from heel to ball of foot curving medially across ball

steps.title: Inspect, palpates, & tests active ROM of bilateral Hips

subSteps.content: Identifies Iliac Crest, ASIS, PSIS, & Greater Trochanter
Flexion (with knee extended 90°; with knee flexed 130° - 150°)
Extension (prone; 5°- 40°)
Adduction (20° - 30°)
Abduction (45°)
Internal Rotation (35°- 45°) & External Rotation (40°-50°)

comments: Range of motion, presence or absence of Crepitus

steps.title: Inspects, palpates, & tests active ROM of bilateral Knees

subSteps.content: Identifies Suprapatellar Pouch, Popliteal Fossa, MCL, LCL, & Tibial Tubercle
Flexion (135°)
Extension (180°)

comments: Ecchymosis, erythema, edema, contour, Genu Varus or Valgum
Range of motion, presence or absence of Crepitus

steps.title: Tests for ACL & PCL Injury

subSteps.content: Anterior/Posterior Drawer Test: knee flexed to 90°, feet flat on table, grasps tibia just below knee with both hands, thumbs placed parallel to patellar tendon, draws tibia anteriorly & pushes tibia posteriorly
Lachman's Test: knee flexed to 20°-30°, grasps proximal tibia with one hand & femur other, pulls tibia anteriorly & pushes tibia posteriorly

steps.title: Tests for MCL & LCL Injury

subSteps.content: Varus Stress Test (LCL): knee flexed to 20-30°, stabilizes distal femur with one hand & applies varus pressure at distal tibia to adduct lower leg slightly
Valgus Stress Test (MCL): knee flexed to 20-30°, stabilizes distal femur with one hand & applies valgus pressure at distal tibia to abduct lower leg while restricting axial rotation

steps.title: Tests for Meniscal Tears with McMurray's Test

subSteps.content: Lateral Tears: With knee in complete flexion, holds bottom of foot with one hand & palpates knee joint with other, internally rotates tibia & extends knee
Medial Tears: With knee in complete flexion, holds bottom of foot with one hand & palpates knee joint with other, externally rotates tibia & extends knee

steps.title: Inspects, palpates, & tests active ROM of bilateral Ankles

subSteps.content: Dorsiflexion (20°)
Plantar Flexion (45°)
Eversion (20°)
Inversion (30°)

steps.title: Tests Trunk Strength
steps.instructions: by assisting patient to sitting position

steps.title: Tests Balance & Gait
steps.instructions: stands near patient to provide support if needed

subSteps.content: Romberg's Test: instructs patient to stand with feet together, then close eyes (assess for 30-60 seconds)
Pronator Drift: instructs patient to stand with arms extended, palms up (assess for 20 seconds)
Natural Gait: instructs patient to walk across room
Tandem Walking: instructs patient to walk heel-to-toe
Toes & Heels: instructs patient to walk across room on toes & back on heels

steps.title: Tests for Meniscal Tears with Duck Walk Test

subSteps.content: Instruct patient to squat completely & waddle forward, backward & side-to-side

steps.title: Inspects, palpates, and test ROM of Spine

subSteps.content: Flexion (75°-90°)
Extension (30°)
Lateral bending (35°)
Rotation

steps.title: Tests for Scoliosis

subSteps.content: Instructs patient to bend forward with feet together, knees locked, arms in diving posture with fingertips aligned, head forward

steps.title: Appropriately concludes the exam with the patient
What is the mechanism of action of Combined Hormonal Contraceptives (CHC)?
comments: Progestins (primary): thicken cervical mucus, slow tubal motility, induce endometrial atrophy, block LH surge, suppress FSH
Estrogen: stabilize endometrial lining, provide cycle control

steps.title: What are the ACHES warning signs for serious COC adverse effects?

subSteps.content: A - Abdominal pain (severe)
C - Chest pain, shortness of breath
H - Headache (severe), vision changes
E - Eye problems (vision loss, diplopia)
S - Severe leg pain/swelling

comments: Stop CHC immediately if any occur

steps.title: What medications decrease COC effectiveness?
What are the starting methods for COC?

subSteps.content: First day of cycle - start day 1, backup 7 days
First Sunday - start first Sunday after cycle begins, backup 7 days
Quick start - start day of office visit, backup 7 days (most successful)

steps.title: How do you manage missed COC doses?

subSteps.content: 1 tablet: take ASAP, continue rest as prescribed
≥2 tablets: take 1 missed tablet ASAP, discard others, continue
If missed in last week: finish active tablets, skip hormone-free interval, start new pack
Use backup contraception until 7 consecutive days of active tablets

steps.title: What are the contraindications for CHC in patients >35 years old?
comments: Do NOT use if >35 yo with:

steps.title: When are CHC contraindicated in smokers?
comments: COC ≥50 mcg EE associated with MI in smokers

steps.title: What are the blood pressure contraindications for CHC?

subSteps.content: Contraindication: SBP ≥160 or DBP ≥100
Risk>benefit: SBP 140-159 or DBP 90-99
CHC can increase BP 6-8 mmHg
BP usually normalizes 3-6 months after D/C

steps.title: What are the transdermal contraceptive options and their administration?

subSteps.content: Xulane: 35 mcg EE + 150 mcg norelgestromin (effective if <90 kg)
Twirla: 30 mcg EE + 120 mcg levonorgestrel (recommended BMI <30)
Apply to abdomen, buttocks, upper torso, or upper arm
Change weekly x3 weeks, then week 4 patch-free

comments: ~60% more estrogen exposure than 35 mcg COC → increased thrombotic risk

steps.title: What are the vaginal ring options and their administration?

subSteps.content: NuvaRing: 15 mcg/day EE + 120 mcg/day etonogestrel - use 3 weeks, discard
Annovera: 13 mcg EE + 150 mcg segesterone - use 3 weeks x13 cycles (reuse)
Insert on/before day 5, remains 3 weeks, remove 1 week
Annovera: avoid tampons (NuvaRing okay with tampons)

steps.title: What are the oral progestin-only contraceptive options?

subSteps.content: Mini pills: Norethindrone 0.35 mg or Norgestrel 0.075 mg (Opill OTC)
Must take same time daily; if >3 hours late: backup x48 hours
Drospirenone 4 mg (Slynd): 24 days active + 4 placebo
Drospirenone: less strict timing, missed = >24 hours late

steps.title: What is Depo-Provera (DMPA) and its administration?

subSteps.content: 150 mg/mL IM (gluteal/deltoid) q3 months
104 mg SubQ (abdomen/thigh) q3 months
If >13 weeks (IM) or >14 weeks (SubQ) → pregnancy test required
Return to fertility: ~10 months

steps.title: What are the key adverse effects of Depo-Provera?

subSteps.content: Most frequent: menstrual irregularities (spotting, prolonged bleeding, amenorrhea)
Weight gain: avg 1 kg annually, resolves 6-8 months after last injection
BLACK BOX WARNING: Short-term bone loss
Continue >2 years ONLY if other methods inadequate
Not recommended with long-term corticosteroids

steps.title: What is Nexplanon and its characteristics?

subSteps.content: 4 cm long subdermal implant, 68 mg etonogestrel
Releases 60 mcg/day first month → 30 mcg/day at 3 years
Duration: up to 3 years
Placed in upper arm by trained clinician
Fertility returns within 30 days of removal

comments: Efficacy may decrease if >130% ideal body weight

steps.title: What are the IUD options available?

subSteps.content: Copper IUD (ParaGard): 10 years, 99% effective
Liletta & Mirena: up to 8 years, 20 mcg/day levonorgestrel
Kyleena: up to 5 years, 17.5 mcg/day levonorgestrel
Skyla: up to 3 years, 14 mcg/day levonorgestrel

steps.title: When should IUDs NOT be inserted?
What are the emergency contraception options?

subSteps.content: Levonorgestrel: 1.5 mg x1 within 72 hours (OTC for all ages)
Ulipristal: 30 mg x1 within 120 hours (prescription only)
Copper IUD (most effective)
Does NOT disrupt existing pregnancy

comments: Implantation usually takes ~5 days after intercourse

steps.title: What are the key differences between levonorgestrel and ulipristal for emergency contraception?

subSteps.content: Levonorgestrel: OTC, within 72 hours, regimen of choice
Ulipristal: Prescription, within 120 hours (5 days)
Ulipristal: not recommended if breastfeeding
Ulipristal: may interfere with hormonal contraception, barrier method x1 month

steps.title: What is the medication regimen for early pregnancy termination?

subSteps.content: For pregnancy ≤70 days
Mifepristone 200 mg day 1
Misoprostol 800 mcg buccally 24-48 hours later
Higher efficacy earlier in pregnancy

comments: Mifepristone: BBW for infection and bleeding
Misoprostol AE: stomach upset, diarrhea, headache, chills, fever

steps.title: What are the stages and timing of menopause?

subSteps.content: Perimenopause: transition period, irregular cycles
Menopause: ≥12 months after last menses
Postmenopause: period after menopause
Average age: 51 years (range 40-58)

comments: Natural life stage, not a disease
Permanent end from loss of ovarian follicle activity

steps.title: What are the vasomotor symptoms of menopause and their management?

subSteps.content: Hot flashes/flushes: sudden heat sensation, sweating, flushing
Most common symptom (~75% of women)
Duration: 30 seconds to 5 minutes
First-line: Hormone therapy (estrogen ± progestin)

steps.title: What are the hormone therapy options for menopause?

subSteps.content: Estrogen-only: for women without uterus (hysterectomy)
Estrogen + progestin: for women with intact uterus
Progestin prevents endometrial hyperplasia/cancer
Use lowest effective dose for shortest duration

steps.title: What are the contraindications for hormone therapy?
comments: Active or history of VTE, DVT, PE
Active or recent arterial thromboembolic disease
Known protein C, protein S, or antithrombin deficiency

steps.title: What are the risks of hormone therapy?

subSteps.content: Increased risk: VTE, stroke, breast cancer (with progestin)
Estrogen-only: increased endometrial cancer risk
Risk increases with duration of use
Higher risk if started >10 years after menopause or age >60

comments: Benefits may outweigh risks if started early (<60 yo or <10 years since menopause)

steps.title: What are the non-hormonal options for vasomotor symptoms?

subSteps.content: Paroxetine 7.5 mg: only FDA-approved non-hormonal (Brisdelle)
Off-label SSRIs/SNRIs: venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, escitalopram
Gabapentin 300 mg TID (off-label)
Avoid: tamoxifen, raloxifene (worsen hot flashes)

comments: Less effective than hormone therapy but useful when HT contraindicated

steps.title: What is the genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM)?

subSteps.content: Vulvovaginal atrophy: dryness, burning, irritation, dyspareunia
Vaginal pH increases (more alkaline)
Treatment: vaginal estrogen therapy (preferred)
Alternative: ospemifene (oral SERM), vaginal DHEA

comments: Vaginal estrogen has minimal systemic absorption

steps.title: What are the vaginal estrogen therapy options?

subSteps.content: Estradiol cream (Estrace): 0.5-2 g daily x2 weeks, then 1-3x/week
Estradiol vaginal insert (Imvexxy): 4 mcg or 10 mcg daily
Estradiol ring (Estring): 2 mg, q90 days
Conjugated estrogen cream (Premarin): 0.5 g daily x3 weeks

comments: Progestin NOT needed with low-dose vaginal estrogen

steps.title: What is osteoporosis and its diagnostic criteria?

subSteps.content: Skeletal disorder: compromised bone strength, increased fracture risk
Diagnosis: T-score ≤-2.5 (DEXA scan)
Osteopenia: T-score -1.0 to -2.5
Normal: T-score ≥-1.0

comments: Estrogen deficiency major risk factor in women

steps.title: What are the risk factors for osteoporosis?

subSteps.content: Non-modifiable: age, female, Caucasian/Asian, family history, small frame
Modifiable: low calcium/vitamin D, sedentary, smoking, excess alcohol
Medical: early menopause, hyperthyroidism, hyperparathyroidism
Medications: glucocorticoids, anticonvulsants, PPIs, SSRIs

steps.title: Who should be screened for osteoporosis?
comments: Adults with conditions associated with low bone mass

steps.title: What are the calcium and vitamin D recommendations for osteoporosis prevention?

subSteps.content: Calcium: 1000-1200 mg/day (diet + supplements)
Vitamin D: 800-1000 IU/day
Calcium carbonate: take with food (needs acid)
Calcium citrate: can take without food

comments: Separate from levothyroxine, bisphosphonates, fluoroquinolones by 2-4 hours

steps.title: What are the bisphosphonate options for osteoporosis?

subSteps.content: Alendronate: 70 mg PO weekly or 10 mg daily
Risedronate: 35 mg PO weekly, 150 mg monthly, or 5 mg daily
Ibandronate: 150 mg PO monthly or 3 mg IV q3 months
Zoledronic acid: 5 mg IV annually

steps.title: What are the administration requirements for oral bisphosphonates?

subSteps.content: Take on empty stomach with 8 oz plain water
Remain upright (sitting/standing) 30-60 minutes
Wait 30-60 minutes before eating, drinking, or other medications
Do not lie down for 30-60 minutes after dose

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of bisphosphonates?

subSteps.content: GI: esophagitis, esophageal ulcers, abdominal pain, nausea
Musculoskeletal pain (can be severe)
Osteonecrosis of jaw (rare, higher with IV)
Atypical femoral fractures (rare, with long-term use)

steps.title: What is denosumab (Prolia) and its dosing?

subSteps.content: RANKL inhibitor: prevents osteoclast formation/function
60 mg SubQ q6 months
Can use in renal impairment (unlike bisphosphonates)
Discontinuation → rapid bone loss and increased fracture risk

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of denosumab?
What is raloxifene (Evista) and its use?

subSteps.content: Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM)
60 mg PO daily
Reduces vertebral fractures (NOT hip)
Also reduces breast cancer risk

steps.title: What is teriparatide (Forteo) and its characteristics?

subSteps.content: Recombinant PTH analog: stimulates bone formation
20 mcg SubQ daily
Maximum duration: 2 years lifetime
For severe osteoporosis or high fracture risk

steps.title: What is romosozumab (Evenity)?

subSteps.content: Sclerostin inhibitor: increases bone formation, decreases resorption
210 mg SubQ monthly x12 months
For postmenopausal women at high fracture risk
BBW: increased cardiovascular risk (MI, stroke)

comments: Contraindicated: MI or stroke within prior year

steps.title: What is the duration of osteoporosis treatment?

subSteps.content: Bisphosphonates: 3-5 years, then reassess
Drug holiday possible if low risk after 3-5 years
Continue if: T-score <-2.5, history of fracture, high risk
Denosumab: no drug holiday (rapid bone loss on discontinuation)

steps.title: How do you monitor osteoporosis treatment?

subSteps.content: DEXA scan: 1-2 years after initiation, then q2 years
Serum calcium, vitamin D levels
Bone turnover markers (optional): CTX, P1NP
Expect BMD increase 1-3% per year

steps.title: What are typical use failure rates for contraceptive methods?

subSteps.content: COC/patch/ring: 7%
Drospirenone-only: 4%
Depo-medroxyprogesterone: 4%
Copper IUD/Levonorgestrel IUD/Implant: <1%

steps.title: When should hormone therapy be avoided postpartum?

subSteps.content: Breastfeeding: avoid estrogen first 21 days postpartum
Breastfeeding with VTE risk: avoid estrogen 42 days; without risk 30 days
Not breastfeeding with VTE risk: avoid estrogen 42 days
Not breastfeeding without VTE risk: avoid 21 days

steps.title: What are the special considerations for CHC and thromboembolism?

subSteps.content: Estrogens increase VTE risk 3X vs nonusers
3rd/4th generation progestins: slightly higher VTE risk
Transdermal/vaginal: increased risk (continuous/higher estrogen)
Progestin-only: no significant increase in venous/arterial events

steps.title: What are key patient counseling points for vaginal ring use?

subSteps.content: If displaced <3 hours (NuvaRing) or <2 hours (Annovera): reinsert, no backup
If displaced >3 hours (NuvaRing) or >2 hours (Annovera): reinsert, backup x7 days
NuvaRing: store in fridge if not using promptly; okay with tampons
Annovera: no refrigeration; avoid tampons; wash and store when removed

steps.title: What are the PK/PD targets for different antibiotic classes?

subSteps.content: T>MIC (Time above MIC): Beta-lactams, macrolides, oxazolidinones
AUC/MIC: Vancomycin, fluoroquinolones, tetracyclines
Cmax/MIC: Aminoglycosides

comments: Optimize Cmax/MIC: high dose, extended interval

steps.title: What are the major mechanisms of beta-lactam resistance?
What is the mechanism of action of beta-lactam antibiotics?

subSteps.content: Inhibit final step of cell wall synthesis
Block cross-linking of peptidoglycan by binding to PBPs
Bactericidal
Time-dependent killing (optimize T>MIC)

steps.title: What is the spectrum of activity for penicillin?
comments: Streptococci: S. pyogenes, S. viridans, S. pneumoniae

steps.title: What are the HELPS bugs covered by aminopenicillins?

subSteps.content: H - H. influenzae
E - E. faecalis
L - L. monocytogenes
P - P. mirabilis
S - Salmonella and Shigella
Also: penicillin-susceptible streptococci

steps.title: What are the penicillin/beta-lactamase inhibitor combinations?

subSteps.content: Amoxicillin/Clavulanic Acid (Augmentin) - PO
Ampicillin/Sulbactam (Unasyn) - IV
Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) - IV

comments: BLI adds: Greater Gram(-) and anaerobic activity, MSSA coverage

steps.title: What is piperacillin/tazobactam used for?
comments: Empiric broad-spectrum therapy for nosocomial infections
Covers: MSSA, Streptococci, Enterococci, P. aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae, anaerobes
Note: Tazobactam offers NO advantage for P. aeruginosa (piperacillin alone active)

steps.title: What are the major adverse effects of penicillins?

subSteps.content: Hypersensitivity reactions (most common): rash, anaphylaxis
GI upset: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (especially Augmentin)
Seizures: with high doses or renal impairment
Drug fever, eosinophilia

steps.title: What are the first-generation cephalosporins and their spectrum?

subSteps.content: Agents: Cefazolin (IV), Cephalexin (PO)
Excellent Gram(+): MSSA, Streptococci
Moderate Gram(-): E. coli, K. pneumoniae, P. mirabilis
Poor: Enterococcus, P. aeruginosa, anaerobes

steps.title: What are the third-generation cephalosporins and their spectrum?

subSteps.content: Ceftriaxone, Cefotaxime, Ceftazidime, Cefpodoxime
Enhanced Gram(-): Enterobacteriaceae
Ceftazidime: adds P. aeruginosa
Decreased MSSA activity vs 1st gen

comments: Ceftriaxone: long half-life (24h dosing), high protein binding

steps.title: What are the fifth-generation cephalosporins?

subSteps.content: Ceftaroline (Teflaro), Ceftobiprole
Activity against MRSA (unique among beta-lactams)
Also covers: Streptococci, Enterobacteriaceae
NO activity: Pseudomonas, Enterococcus

comments: Use: Skin infections with MRSA, CAP

steps.title: What is cefepime and its spectrum?

subSteps.content: Fourth-generation cephalosporin
Broad spectrum: Gram(+) and Gram(-)
Covers: MSSA, Streptococci, Enterobacteriaceae, P. aeruginosa
Does NOT cover: MRSA, Enterococcus, anaerobes

comments: Common empiric agent for nosocomial infections

steps.title: What are the carbapenem options and their spectrum?

subSteps.content: Imipenem/Cilastatin, Meropenem, Ertapenem, Doripenem
Broadest spectrum beta-lactams
Covers: MSSA, Streptococci, Enterobacteriaceae, P. aeruginosa (except ertapenem), anaerobes
Does NOT cover: MRSA, Enterococcus faecium, atypicals

comments: Ertapenem: NO Pseudomonas or Enterococcus coverage

steps.title: What is aztreonam and when is it used?

subSteps.content: Monobactam (only one available)
Spectrum: Gram(-) ONLY (Enterobacteriaceae, P. aeruginosa)
NO Gram(+) or anaerobic activity
Safe in penicillin/cephalosporin allergy (different ring structure)

comments: Use: Beta-lactam allergic patients needing Gram(-) coverage

steps.title: What are Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamases (ESBLs)?

subSteps.content: Enzymes that hydrolyze penicillins and cephalosporins
Common in: E. coli, K. pneumoniae
Treatment: Carbapenems (drug of choice)
Alternative: Piperacillin/tazobactam (if susceptible and not severe)

steps.title: What are Carbapenem-Resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE)?

subSteps.content: Produce carbapenemases (KPC most common in US)
Resistant to: ALL beta-lactams
Treatment: Polymyxins (colistin, polymyxin B), tigecycline, newer agents
Newer agents: Meropenem/vaborbactam, imipenem/relebactam, ceftazidime/avibactam

steps.title: What is the only treatment indication for asymptomatic bacteriuria?
comments: Do NOT treat otherwise - leads to increased resistance, C. diff, adverse events, INCREASES recurrent UTIs
#1 cause of inappropriate antimicrobial usage in hospitals

steps.title: What antibiotics have highest C. difficile risk?

subSteps.content: 3rd gen cephalosporins: OR 3.20
Clindamycin: OR 2.86
2nd gen cephalosporins: OR 2.23
Cefepime: OR 2.14
Carbapenems: OR 1.84

steps.title: What are the cephalosporin generations and their uses?

subSteps.content: 1st gen: Excellent Gram(+), moderate Gram(-); Use: Skin infections, surgical prophylaxis
2nd gen: Improved Gram(-); Use: Respiratory, intra-abdominal
3rd gen: Enhanced Gram(-), some Pseudomonas (ceftazidime); Use: Meningitis, CAP
4th gen (Cefepime): Broad Gram(+) and Gram(-), Pseudomonas
5th gen (Ceftaroline): Adds MRSA coverage

steps.title: What is the difference between empiric and definitive therapy?

subSteps.content: Empiric: Therapy before causative organism known; based on common pathogens
Definitive: Once cultures and sensitivities available; targeted therapy
Always try to de-escalate from empiric to definitive

steps.title: What are the goals of antimicrobial stewardship?
comments: Optimize clinical outcomes (appropriate selection, dose, route, duration)
Minimize emergence of resistant pathogens (MRSA, VRE, MDR organisms)

steps.title: What is the cost and impact of antimicrobial resistance?

subSteps.content: Total annual cost: ~$30 billion
MRSA bacteremia: 1.9x mortality, +2.2 days, +$6,916
VRE: 2.1x mortality, +6.2 days, +$12,766
Resistant Pseudomonas: 3.0x mortality, +5.7 days
Resistant Enterobacter: 5.0x mortality, +9 days, +$29,379

steps.title: What are penicillinase-resistant penicillins and their use?

subSteps.content: Agents: Nafcillin, Oxacillin, Dicloxacillin
Designed to overcome penicillinase
Spectrum: MSSA, Streptococci
Does NOT cover: MRSA (all beta-lactams inactive), Gram(-), Enterococcus, anaerobes

comments: Methicillin not clinically used but important for nomenclature (MSSA/MRSA)

steps.title: How does MRSA develop resistance to beta-lactams?

subSteps.content: PBP2 → PBP2A alteration
PBP2A has decreased affinity for all beta-lactams
Can carry out transpeptidation even with beta-lactams present
Confers resistance to ALL beta-lactams (except ceftaroline)

steps.title: What organisms are covered by piperacillin/tazobactam?
comments: Does NOT cover: MRSA, E. faecium, atypicals

steps.title: What is benzathine penicillin and its use?

subSteps.content: Long-acting depot preparation
Must be given IM
Slow steady release → low-level concentration for long period
Use: Syphilis (all stages)

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of cephalosporins?

subSteps.content: Hypersensitivity: Cross-reactivity with penicillins ~1-2%
GI upset: nausea, diarrhea
Ceftriaxone: biliary sludging, do NOT use in neonates (kernicterus)
Disulfiram-like reaction: cefotetan with alcohol

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of carbapenems?

subSteps.content: Seizures: especially imipenem (highest risk), with high doses or renal impairment
GI upset: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
Hypersensitivity: cross-reactivity with penicillins (~1%)

comments: Meropenem has lower seizure risk than imipenem

steps.title: What is the spectrum and use of ertapenem?

subSteps.content: Covers: MSSA, Streptococci, Enterobacteriaceae, anaerobes
Does NOT cover: Pseudomonas, Enterococcus, MRSA
Once-daily dosing
Use: Community-acquired intra-abdominal infections, complicated UTI

steps.title: What are the newer beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor combinations?

subSteps.content: Ceftazidime/Avibactam: covers CRE, ESBL, AmpC, Pseudomonas
Meropenem/Vaborbactam: covers CRE (KPC), Enterobacteriaceae
Imipenem/Relebactam: covers Pseudomonas, some CRE
Ceftolozane/Tazobactam: enhanced Pseudomonas coverage

steps.title: What is the clinical use of first-generation cephalosporins?
What are the key characteristics of ceftriaxone?

subSteps.content: Long half-life: allows once-daily dosing
High protein binding
Biliary excretion (can cause sludging)
Do NOT use in neonates (displaces bilirubin → kernicterus)

comments: Use: Meningitis, gonorrhea, CAP, Lyme disease

steps.title: What defines susceptible, intermediate, and resistant?

subSteps.content: Susceptible: PK/PD targets achievable, expect clinical success with common doses
Intermediate: MICs elevated, might see success with dose optimization
Resistant: PK/PD targets not obtainable, would NOT expect clinical success

steps.title: What are the steps for selecting empiric antimicrobials?

subSteps.content: 1. Have a working diagnosis
2. Know common pathogens for expected infection
3. Consider patient-specific factors (allergies, previous abx, organ disease, history of resistance)
4. Obtain cultures
5. Start empiric therapy
6. Await diagnostics
7. Streamline/de-escalate based on cultures

steps.title: What is the relationship between antibiotic exposure and resistance?

subSteps.content: Previous antibiotic exposure in last 90 days increases resistance risk
More exposures → higher odds ratio (0 exposures: OR 1.0; ≥3: OR 2.93)
Each additional day of antibiotics: OR 1.04 for resistance
Carbapenem use correlates with CRE isolates

steps.title: What distinguishes bactericidal from bacteriostatic antibiotics?

subSteps.content: Bactericidal: Number of bacteria decrease when exposed (kill bacteria)
Bacteriostatic: Number stays the same (inhibit growth, host kills)
Bactericidal: Beta-lactams, fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, metronidazole
Bacteriostatic: Tetracyclines, macrolides, linezolid, clindamycin

steps.title: When are enterococcal infections treated with synergistic combinations?

subSteps.content: Ampicillin ALONE only bacteriostatic against E. faecalis
For life-threatening infections: endocarditis, osteomyelitis
Use ampicillin + (ceftriaxone OR gentamicin) for synergy
Achieves bactericidal activity

steps.title: What percentage of antibiotic use is inappropriate in different settings?
comments: Asymptomatic bacteriuria: #1 cause of inappropriate hospital use

steps.title: What are AmpC beta-lactamases?

subSteps.content: Chromosomally-encoded (Enterobacter, Citrobacter, Serratia, Morganella)
Confer resistance to: 1st/2nd/3rd gen cephalosporins, penicillins
Susceptible to: Cefepime, carbapenems
NOT inhibited by traditional beta-lactamase inhibitors

steps.title: What are the major clinically important bacteria to know?

subSteps.content: Gram(+): Streptococcus spp., S. aureus, Enterococcus spp.
Enteric Gram(-): E. coli, K. pneumoniae, Proteus spp.
Nosocomial Gram(-): P. aeruginosa, A. baumannii, Enterobacter, Citrobacter, Serratia
Others: Anaerobes, respiratory organisms, C. difficile

steps.title: What is vancomycin and its mechanism of action?

subSteps.content: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to D-Ala-D-Ala
Bactericidal against most Gram-positive organisms
Excellent activity: MRSA, MSSA, Streptococcus, Enterococcus
NO activity: Gram-negative organisms

steps.title: What is the dosing and monitoring for vancomycin?

subSteps.content: Standard: 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h
Loading dose: 25-30 mg/kg for serious infections
Target trough: 15-20 mcg/mL for serious infections
AUC/MIC targeting preferred: target AUC 400-600

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of vancomycin?

subSteps.content: Nephrotoxicity: dose-dependent, risk ↑ with trough >20 mcg/mL
Ototoxicity: rare, associated with high troughs
Red Man Syndrome: histamine-mediated infusion reaction
Thrombophlebitis: common with peripheral IV

comments: Red Man prevention: slow infusion (≥1 hour per 500 mg), antihistamines

steps.title: What is daptomycin and its characteristics?

subSteps.content: Lipopeptide that depolarizes bacterial cell membrane
Concentration-dependent bactericidal activity
Spectrum: Gram-positive only (MRSA, MSSA, VRE, Strep)
NOT effective for pneumonia (inactivated by surfactant)

steps.title: What is the dosing and monitoring for daptomycin?

subSteps.content: ABSSSI: 4 mg/kg IV q24h
Bacteremia/endocarditis: 6-8 mg/kg q24h (up to 10-12 mg/kg)
Adjust for CrCl <30 mL/min: dose q48h
Monitor CPK weekly

comments: D/C if CPK >1000 U/L with symptoms or >2000 U/L

steps.title: What is linezolid and its characteristics?

subSteps.content: Oxazolidinone: inhibits protein synthesis (50S ribosomal subunit)
Spectrum: MRSA, VRE, Strep
Dosing: 600 mg PO/IV q12h
100% oral bioavailability, excellent tissue penetration

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of linezolid?

subSteps.content: Myelosuppression: thrombocytopenia, anemia (monitor CBC weekly if >2 weeks)
Peripheral/optic neuropathy: with prolonged use >28 days
Lactic acidosis: rare
Serotonin syndrome: with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOIs

comments: MAO inhibitor activity - avoid tyramine-rich foods

steps.title: What are treatment options for VRE?
comments: Daptomycin: 8-12 mg/kg q24h (higher doses for endocarditis)

steps.title: What are the fluoroquinolones and their spectrum?

subSteps.content: MOA: Inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
Concentration-dependent bactericidal activity
PK/PD target: AUC/MIC >30-40 (Gram-neg), >100 (Strep)
Broad coverage: Gram(+), Gram(-), atypicals

steps.title: What are the individual fluoroquinolone agents and their uses?

subSteps.content: Levofloxacin: CAP, UTI, ABSSSI, prostatitis (500-750 mg q24h)
Moxifloxacin: CAP, enhanced Gram(+) and anaerobic (400 mg q24h, NOT for UTI)
Ciprofloxacin: Excellent Gram(-) including Pseudomonas, UTI (250-750 mg q12h)
Delafloxacin: ABSSSI including MRSA (300 mg IV or 450 mg PO q12h)

steps.title: What are the Black Box Warnings for fluoroquinolones?

subSteps.content: Tendon rupture/tendinitis (especially Achilles)
Peripheral neuropathy (may be permanent)
CNS effects: seizures, increased ICP
Aortic aneurysm/dissection
Myasthenia gravis exacerbation (contraindicated)

comments: FDA: reserve for serious infections when alternatives unavailable

steps.title: What are other adverse effects and interactions of fluoroquinolones?

subSteps.content: QTc prolongation (greatest with moxifloxacin)
Photosensitivity, GI upset
Dysglycemia, C. difficile
Divalent/trivalent cations: separate by 2-6 hours (antacids, Ca, Fe, Zn)

steps.title: What are the aminoglycosides and their characteristics?

subSteps.content: MOA: Bind 30S ribosomal subunit, inhibit protein synthesis
Concentration-dependent bactericidal (PK/PD: Cmax/MIC 8-10)
Spectrum: Gram-negatives (including Pseudomonas)
NO activity: Anaerobes (require oxygen for uptake)

steps.title: What is extended-interval dosing for aminoglycosides?

subSteps.content: Gentamicin/Tobramycin: 5-7 mg/kg q24h
Amikacin: 15-20 mg/kg q24h
Advantages: enhanced efficacy, reduced toxicity, convenient
Monitoring: random level 6-14 hours post-dose

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of aminoglycosides?

subSteps.content: Nephrotoxicity (10-25%): usually reversible, monitor SCr/BUN
Ototoxicity: vestibular (vertigo) and cochlear (hearing loss, often permanent)
Neuromuscular blockade: rare
Risk factors: prolonged therapy, high levels, concurrent nephro/ototoxins

steps.title: What are the macrolides and their spectrum?

subSteps.content: MOA: Bind 50S ribosomal subunit, inhibit protein synthesis
Bacteriostatic (bactericidal at high concentrations)
Spectrum: Gram(+), atypicals (Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, Legionella)
Some Gram(-): H. influenzae (azithromycin)

steps.title: What are the individual macrolide agents?

subSteps.content: Erythromycin: 250-500 mg q6h, poor GI tolerance, significant drug interactions
Clarithromycin: 250-500 mg q12h, better tolerated, strong CYP3A4 inhibitor
Azithromycin: 500 mg x1 then 250 mg q24h x4d (Z-Pak), long half-life (68h)
Azithromycin: once-daily, short courses, fewer interactions, best GI tolerance

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of macrolides?

subSteps.content: GI: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (motilin receptor agonist)
QTc prolongation: all macrolides (greatest with azithromycin)
Hepatotoxicity: rare cholestatic hepatitis
CYP3A4 inhibition: erythro > clarithro >> azithro

comments: FDA warning: increased CV death risk with azithromycin

steps.title: What is doxycycline and its uses?

subSteps.content: Tetracycline: binds 30S ribosomal subunit, bacteriostatic
Dosing: 100 mg PO/IV q12h, 90-100% oral bioavailability
Spectrum: Broad (Gram+/-, atypicals, rickettsiae, MRSA)
Uses: CAP, tick-borne diseases, ABSSSI, acne, malaria prophylaxis

comments: Drug of choice for tick-borne illnesses (Lyme, RMSF, ehrlichiosis)

steps.title: What is tigecycline and its characteristics?

subSteps.content: Glycylcycline (tetracycline derivative)
Broad spectrum: MRSA, VRE, ESBL, anaerobes
NO activity: Pseudomonas, Proteus
Dosing: 100 mg IV x1, then 50 mg IV q12h

comments: BLACK BOX: increased mortality vs comparators - reserve for limited options

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of tetracyclines?

subSteps.content: GI: nausea, vomiting, esophagitis (take with water, stay upright)
Photosensitivity: severe sunburn with minimal sun
Tooth discoloration: permanent in children <8 years
Chelation: separate from Ca, Fe, Mg, Al by 2-3 hours

steps.title: What is clindamycin and its spectrum?

subSteps.content: Inhibits protein synthesis (50S), bacteriostatic
Spectrum: Gram(+) cocci (MRSA), anaerobes (B. fragilis)
NO activity: Gram(-), Enterococcus
Dosing: 150-450 mg PO q6-8h, 600-900 mg IV q8h

steps.title: What is TMP/SMX and its characteristics?

subSteps.content: Sequential blockade of folic acid synthesis, bactericidal
Spectrum: MRSA, MSSA, Gram(-), PCP, Stenotrophomonas
Dosing: 1 DS tablet PO q12h (standard), higher for PCP
Uses: UTI (first-line), MRSA ABSSSI, PCP treatment/prophylaxis

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of TMP/SMX?

subSteps.content: Hyperkalemia: trimethoprim = K-sparing diuretic
Nephrotoxicity: ↑SCr (blocks tubular secretion, not true damage)
Rash: common (3-5%), Stevens-Johnson in severe cases
Drug interactions: warfarin (↑INR), methotrexate, phenytoin

comments: Monitor K+ and SCr during therapy

steps.title: What is metronidazole and its uses?

subSteps.content: Disrupts DNA, bactericidal against anaerobes
Spectrum: Anaerobes (Bacteroides, Clostridium including C. diff)
Uses: C. diff, intra-abdominal infections, bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis
Dosing: 500 mg PO/IV q8h (C. diff), 2g x1 (trich)

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of metronidazole?

subSteps.content: Disulfiram-like reaction: severe with alcohol (avoid during + 3 days after)
Metallic taste: very common
Peripheral neuropathy: prolonged use >2 weeks
Drug interactions: warfarin (↑INR), lithium

steps.title: What is rifampin and its uses?

subSteps.content: Inhibits bacterial RNA polymerase, bactericidal
ALWAYS combination therapy (rapid resistance if alone)
Uses: TB, Staph prosthetic joint infections, MRSA bacteremia (adjunct)
Meningitis prophylaxis: N. meningitidis, H. influenzae

steps.title: What are the adverse effects of rifampin?

subSteps.content: Orange discoloration: urine, tears, sweat (warn patients, stains contacts)
Hepatotoxicity: monitor LFTs
Potent CYP3A4 inducer: decreases levels of many drugs
Decreases: oral contraceptives, warfarin, protease inhibitors

steps.title: What is nitrofurantoin and its uses?

subSteps.content: Damages bacterial DNA, bactericidal at urinary concentrations
Spectrum: E. coli, Enterococcus, S. saprophyticus
NO activity: Pseudomonas, Proteus, Serratia, many Klebsiella
Use: Uncomplicated UTI (cystitis) ONLY, NOT pyelonephritis

comments: Dosing: 100 mg PO q12h x5-7 days

steps.title: What are the adverse effects and contraindications of nitrofurantoin?

subSteps.content: Pulmonary toxicity: acute pneumonitis or chronic fibrosis (risk ↑ with >6 months)
Peripheral neuropathy: especially with renal impairment
Contraindications: CrCl <30 mL/min, pregnancy at term, G6PD deficiency
Take with food to reduce GI upset

comments: Only achieves therapeutic levels in urine
Monitor for pulmonary symptoms during long-term use

steps.title: What are the newer lipoglycopeptides?

subSteps.content: Telavancin (Vibativ): 10 mg/kg IV q24h, MRSA skin infections, HAP
Dalbavancin (Dalvance): 1500 mg x1 OR 1000mg + 500mg week later
Oritavancin (Orbactiv): 1200 mg single dose
Advantage: Single-dose therapy for ABSSSI

comments: Outpatient parenteral therapy without IV access maintenance

steps.title: What is tedizolid?

subSteps.content: Second-generation oxazolidinone
Dosing: 200 mg PO/IV q24h x6 days
Indication: ABSSSI
Advantages: Lower myelosuppression, once-daily dosing

steps.title: What is amikacin and when is it used?

subSteps.content: Aminoglycoside resistant to many modifying enzymes
Reserve for resistant organisms
Dosing: 15-20 mg/kg q24h
Same spectrum and toxicity as gentamicin/tobramycin

steps.title: What are the newer tetracyclines?

subSteps.content: Eravacycline (Xerava): complicated intra-abdominal, 1 mg/kg IV q12h
Omadacycline (Nuzyra): CAP, ABSSSI, oral and IV formulations
Advantages: less nausea than tigecycline, active against some tigecycline-resistant

steps.title: What C. difficile risk does clindamycin have?
comments: High risk for C. difficile infection (10-30%)
OR 2.86 for C. diff in meta-analysis
Good for: bone infections, ABSSSI, aspiration pneumonia, toxin suppression

steps.title: What are the usual organisms in skin and soft tissue infections?
comments: Common disease states: Impetigo, Erysipelas (think strep!), Cellulitis

steps.title: What is the treatment for S. pyogenes?

subSteps.content: Drug of choice: Penicillin (nearly universally susceptible)
Narrow spectrum therapy
Most Gram(+) agents cover (EXCEPT doxycycline)
Clindamycin has resistance issues

steps.title: When should MRSA be covered in cellulitis?
comments: Routine coverage: purulent cellulitis and abscesses
Usually NOT warranted in systemic infections without these characteristics

steps.title: What are the oral options for S. aureus?

subSteps.content: MSSA: Cephalexin, Amoxicillin/clavulanate, Dicloxacillin
MRSA: TMP/SMX, Doxycycline, Linezolid
All cover S. pyogenes EXCEPT doxycycline
Follow up at 24-48 hours prudent

steps.title: What is the treatment for severe cellulitis?

subSteps.content: Defined by: failure of oral abx + debridement, systemic symptoms
MSSA/Strep only: Nafcillin or Cefazolin
MRSA: Vancomycin or Daptomycin
Duration: 5-7 days (guideline: 7 days), up to 14 days if started IV

steps.title: What is the treatment for animal bites?

subSteps.content: Must cover Pasteurella multocida (has beta-lactamase)
DOC: Amoxicillin/clavulanic acid
IV: Ampicillin/sulbactam or 3G cephalosporin
Alternatives (PCN allergy): Doxycycline, Moxifloxacin

comments: Cat bites more likely to get infected than dog bites

steps.title: What is the treatment for diabetic foot ulcers?

subSteps.content: Organisms: S. aureus (MRSA) predominate; Gram(-) in deep ulcers
Uninfected ulcers: do NOT treat
Empiric: Vancomycin +/- Ceftriaxone (varies)
Duration: 1-2 wk mild; 2-4 wk moderate; 4-6 wk if bone involvement

comments: Do not treat until ulcer heals - just until infection resolves

steps.title: What is the treatment for uncomplicated cystitis?

subSteps.content: Target: E. coli (based on local susceptibility)
3 days: TMP/SMX, Fluoroquinolones (not moxifloxacin)
5 days: Nitrofurantoin
7 days: Beta-lactams

steps.title: What is fosfomycin and its use?

subSteps.content: MOA: Inhibits enolpyruvate transferase (peptidoglycan synthesis)
Dosing: 3g PO x1 for cystitis
Safe for pregnancy
Recent evidence: inferior to nitrofurantoin, consider second-line

steps.title: What defines a complicated UTI?

subSteps.content: Structural/functional abnormality: obstruction, foreign body, males
Pyelonephritis
Recent guidelines: extending beyond the bladder
Extends duration to 7+ days

steps.title: What is the treatment for community-acquired pyelonephritis?

subSteps.content: Oral: FQ, TMP/SMX (first-line)
NOT appropriate: Nitrofurantoin, Fosfomycin (inadequate tissue levels)
IV: FQ, Aminoglycosides, Ceftriaxone, Carbapenems (if resistant)
Duration: 7-14 days (7 days standard, even with bacteremia)

steps.title: What are 'The Big 6' CAP bacterial pathogens?

subSteps.content: S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis
M. pneumoniae, C. pneumoniae, L. pneumophilia
Others: S. aureus (CA-MRSA, post-influenza)
Anaerobes: only cover for empyema, lung abscess

steps.title: What is outpatient treatment for CAP?

subSteps.content: Healthy adults: Amoxicillin or Doxycycline (macrolides NO longer recommended)
With comorbidities/recent abx: Beta-lactam + (Doxy or Macrolide)
Alternative: Respiratory fluoroquinolone
Duration: minimum 5 days (some data: 3 days sufficient)

steps.title: What is inpatient treatment for CAP?

subSteps.content: Non-severe (floor): Beta-lactam + (Doxy or Macrolide) OR Respiratory FQ
Severe (ICU): Same as above, tetracyclines not listed
Consider vancomycin (not guideline recommendation)
Can transition to oral when stable

steps.title: What happened to HCAP?
comments: Now: previous microbiology is primary driver for MRSA, Pseudomonas coverage
Recent hospitalization/SNF + broad-spectrum abx also considered
Detailed history, personalized approach is key

steps.title: What are the organisms and empiric therapy for HAP/VAP?

subSteps.content: Organisms: S. aureus (MRSA), P. aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae, ESBL
Empiric: Vancomycin or Linezolid + Anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam
Plus/minus: Anti-pseudomonal FQ or Aminoglycoside
De-escalate! Duration: 7 days (historically 14-21)

steps.title: What is COVID-19 outpatient treatment?

subSteps.content: Goal: Stop progression to hospital/death
Nirmatrelvir/ritonavir (Paxlovid): protease inhibitor, MANY drug interactions
Remdesivir: RNA polymerase inhibitor, IV only
Molnupiravir: contraindication in pregnant/pregnancy potential

steps.title: What is COVID-19 hospitalized treatment?

subSteps.content: Room air (moderate): supportive care, consider outpatient therapies if high risk
Hypoxia (moderate-severe): Remdesivir, dexamethasone, +/- tocilizumab or baricitinib
Mechanical ventilation (critical): Dexamethasone, tocilizumab or baricitinib

steps.title: What is influenza treatment?
comments: Vaccination is key (less efficacious than COVID vaccines)
Treatment modestly effective, must start early
Oseltamivir: mainstay, 5 days (longer for critically ill)

steps.title: When should acute bronchitis be treated with antibiotics?

subSteps.content: Vast majority viral - antimicrobials NOT warranted
Exceptions: B. pertussis (macrolides), Influenza (oseltamivir)
Mycoplasma/Chlamydia: macrolide, doxycycline
Symptomatic treatment is mainstay

steps.title: What is treatment for COPD exacerbation?

subSteps.content: Who gets abx: 3 cardinal symptoms (dyspnea, sputum volume, purulence) or 2 if purulence
Oral: Amoxicillin/clavulanate, Doxycycline, Macrolides, Respiratory FQs
IV: For risk factors (comorbidities, severe COPD, frequent exacerbations)
Duration: 5-7 days

steps.title: When should sinusitis be treated with antibiotics?

subSteps.content: Usually viral - only treat if:
1. Persistence >10 days with no improvement
2. Severe symptoms (fever >39 + purulent discharge/facial pain ≥3-4 days)
3. Worsening symptoms
Treatment: Amoxicillin/clavulanate, Doxycycline, FQ; Duration: 5-7 days

steps.title: What are the empiric regimens for bacterial meningitis by age?

subSteps.content: <1 month: Ampicillin + gentamicin (or cefotaxime, avoid ceftriaxone)
1-23 months & 2-50 years: Vancomycin + 3G cephalosporin
>50 years: Vancomycin + 3G cephalosporin + ampicillin (for Listeria)
Dexamethasone 10mg q6h x4 days (give PRIOR to first abx)

steps.title: What antibiotics have good CNS penetration?

subSteps.content: Sufficient: 3rd/4th gen cephalosporins, Penicillin, Ampicillin
Vancomycin, TMP/SMX, Fluoroquinolones, Metronidazole
Insufficient: Tetracyclines, Aminoglycosides, Polymyxins
Use IV at maximal doses, bactericidal preferred

steps.title: What is the treatment for Listeria meningitis?

subSteps.content: DOC: Ampicillin (HELPS bug)
Alternatives: TMP/SMX (good efficacy), Meropenem
Gentamicin sometimes added (but 'silly' per notes)
Risk: >50 yo, pregnant, immunocompromised

steps.title: What is meningitis prophylaxis?

subSteps.content: N. meningitidis: household contacts, oral secretion exposure
Treatment: Ciprofloxacin x1 (alternatives: Rifampin 2d, Ceftriaxone IM)
H. influenzae: everyone in household with unvaccinated children
Treatment: Rifampin

steps.title: What is the treatment for SBP (spontaneous bacterial peritonitis)?

subSteps.content: Common in cirrhosis → ascites
Organisms: E. coli, Streptococcus, Klebsiella
Treatment: 3rd generation cephalosporins
Duration: 5-7 days
Prophylaxis (high risk/history): TMP/SMX 5d/wk or Cipro weekly

steps.title: What is the treatment for intra-abdominal infections?

subSteps.content: Organisms: B. fragilis, E. coli
Community-acquired: Cephalosporin + metronidazole OR Cefoxitin
Nosocomial/critically ill: Cefepime/MTZ, Pip/tazo, Carbapenem
Duration: 4-5 days with source control (guideline recommendation)

steps.title: What is the current treatment for C. difficile?

subSteps.content: D/C broad-spectrum abx and acid-suppressive agents if possible
Fidaxomicin (superior but costly) or Oral vancomycin
Metronidazole almost never recommended (inferior)
Duration: 10-14 days; recurrence common (consider FMT)

steps.title: What is the treatment for chlamydia?

subSteps.content: Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID x7 days (first-line per 2021 guidelines)
Azithromycin 1g x1
Doxycycline superior for rectal chlamydia in MSM
Partners: evaluate if sexual contact in last 60 days; abstain x7 days

steps.title: What is the treatment for gonorrhea?

subSteps.content: Uncomplicated: Ceftriaxone 500mg IM x1 (≥150kg = 1g)
PLUS Doxycycline 100mg PO x7 days (unless chlamydia ruled out)
Disseminated (septic arthritis, endocarditis): Full-dose 3G ceph IV
Duration depends on site

steps.title: What is the treatment for syphilis by stage?

subSteps.content: Penicillin preferred for ALL stages
Primary/Secondary: Benzathine penicillin IM x1
Latent (late): 3 doses at 1-week intervals
Neurosyphilis: High-dose IV penicillin

steps.title: What is the treatment for bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis?

subSteps.content: Bacterial vaginosis (anaerobes): Metronidazole x7 days
Trichomoniasis: Metronidazole 2g PO x1 dose
Candidiasis: Fluconazole 150mg x1 (or topicals)

steps.title: What is the treatment for pelvic inflammatory disease?

subSteps.content: Organisms: N. gonorrhea, C. trachomatis, Gram(-), anaerobes
Empiric: Cefoxitin + doxycycline
Can transition to oral if mild-moderate or clinical response
Cover same organisms

steps.title: What is the treatment for genital herpes?

subSteps.content: First episode: Valacyclovir or Acyclovir x7-10 days
Suppressive (≥6 episodes/yr): Valacyclovir daily (reduces freq 70-80%)
Episodic: 5-day course
Severe (disseminated): IV acyclovir 5-10 mg/kg q8h, then PO to complete 10d

comments: Drugs do NOT eradicate latent virus
